maml:description.maml:para: Generates an APRS-IS passcode for a given callsign.
To send a message to the APRS-IS network, a user must authenticate with a procedurally-generated password. This cmdlet can create that.
Note that this module's Send-* cmdlets will call this function for you. This is merely provided as a convenience.
Your callsign, with or without an SSID. If you specify an SSID, it will be ignored, as it has no bearing on the generated passcode.
Your callsign, with or without an SSID. If you specify an SSID, it will be ignored, as it has no bearing on the generated passcode.

maml:alert.maml:para: These passcodes are algorithmically generated and cannot be changed. Please do not use this knowledge for evil.

dev:remarks.maml:para: If you happen to be working at ARRL headquarters and you need to know your passcode, this is how you could find it out.

maml:description.maml:para: Sends an APRS announcement to the APRS-IS network.
This cmdlet will create and send an APRS announcement to the APRS-IS network. If you do not specify a server and/or port name, the packet will be printed to the screen instead.
The sender's callsign, with or without an SSID. This will almost always be yours or your club's callsign.
You must specify an announcement identifier. This is a single uppercase letter.
The announcement text. It may be up to 67 characters in length, and can contain any ASCII characters except for pipe ('|') and tilde ('~').
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Send this announcement via APRS-IS without confirming. This will only happen if your $ConfirmPreference is set to "Low".
The TCP port used to connect to the APRS-IS server. By default, this is port 14580.
The fully-qualified domain name of the APRS-IS server. By default, rotate.aprs2.net is used, but it is best practice to provide your regional server's name.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run, and no data is sent to APRS-IS.
To include a position report, specify the -Latitude and -Longitude parameters, with your location in decimal degrees north. To specify a location in the Southern Hemisphere, use a negative number.
To include a position report, specify the -Latitude and -Longitude parameters, with your location in decimal degrees east. To specify a location in the Western Hemisphere, use a negative number.
You must specify an announcement identifier. This is a single uppercase letter.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Send this announcement via APRS-IS without confirming. This will only happen if your $ConfirmPreference is set to "Low".
The sender's callsign, with or without an SSID. This will almost always be yours or your club's callsign.
The announcement text. It may be up to 67 characters in length, and can contain any ASCII characters except for pipe ('|') and tilde ('~').
The TCP port used to connect to the APRS-IS server. By default, this is port 14580.
The fully-qualified domain name of the APRS-IS server. By default, rotate.aprs2.net is used, but it is best practice to provide your regional server's name.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run, and no data is sent to APRS-IS.
To include a position report, specify the -Latitude and -Longitude parameters, with your location in decimal degrees north. To specify a location in the Southern Hemisphere, use a negative number.
To include a position report, specify the -Latitude and -Longitude parameters, with your location in decimal degrees east. To specify a location in the Western Hemisphere, use a negative number.
This cmdlet can accept message data through the pipeline.
If you specify APRS-IS server information, the group bulletin will be sent to the APRS-IS network. No data is returned to the pipeline.
If you do not specify APRS-IS server information, the message packet will be returned. You will have to send it via some other manner.

maml:alert.maml:para: Announcements are typically made for situations leading up to an event, in contrast to bulletins which are typically used within the event.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Send-APRSAnnouncement -From "GR8CLUB" -AnnouncementID "S" -Message "There will be a SKYWARN net on GreatClub's repeater Sunday at 8:00 PM." -Server noam.aprs2.net

dev:remarks.maml:para: Send an announcement to the APRS-IS network, advertising GreatClub's weekly SKYWARN net.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Send-APRSAnnouncement -From "GR8CLUB" -AnnouncementID 'R' -Message "Anyone providing emcomm for the road race should meet here." -Latitude 67.890 -Longitude -123.4567

dev:remarks.maml:para: Send an announcement to the APRS-IS network with a position report included.

maml:description.maml:para: Sends an APRS bulletin.
This cmdlet will generate and send an APRS bulletin with a given identifying number.
Specify an APRS-IS server and/or port in order to send it via APRS-IS; otherwise, it will be printed to the screen.
The sender's callsign, with or without an SSID. This will almost always be yours or your club's callsign.
Provide a bulletin identifier between zero and nine (inclusive). The identifier is not defined in the APRS specification, and should be interpreted by the receiver.
The bulletin text. Bulletin text may be up to 67 characters in length, and can contain any ASCII characters except for pipe ('|') and tilde ('~').
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Send this bulletin via APRS-IS without confirming. This will only happen if your $ConfirmPreference is set to "Low".
The TCP port used to connect to the APRS-IS server. By default, this is port 14580.
The fully-qualified domain name of the APRS-IS server. By default, rotate.aprs2.net is used, but it is best practice to provide your regional server's name.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run, and no data is sent to APRS-IS.
To include a position report, specify the -Latitude and -Longitude parameters, with your location in decimal degrees north. To specify a location in the Southern Hemisphere, use a negative number.
To include a position report, specify the -Latitude and -Longitude parameters, with your location in decimal degrees east. To specify a location in the Western Hemisphere, use a negative number.
Provide a bulletin identifier between zero and nine (inclusive). The identifier is not defined in the APRS specification, and should be interpreted by the receiver.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Send this bulletin via APRS-IS without confirming. This will only happen if your $ConfirmPreference is set to "Low".
The sender's callsign, with or without an SSID. This will almost always be yours or your club's callsign.
The bulletin text. Bulletin text may be up to 67 characters in length, and can contain any ASCII characters except for pipe ('|') and tilde ('~').
The TCP port used to connect to the APRS-IS server. By default, this is port 14580.
The fully-qualified domain name of the APRS-IS server. By default, rotate.aprs2.net is used, but it is best practice to provide your regional server's name.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run, and no data is sent to APRS-IS.
To include a position report, specify the -Latitude and -Longitude parameters, with your location in decimal degrees north. To specify a location in the Southern Hemisphere, use a negative number.
To include a position report, specify the -Latitude and -Longitude parameters, with your location in decimal degrees east. To specify a location in the Western Hemisphere, use a negative number.
This cmdlet can accept message data through the pipeline.
If you specify APRS-IS server information, the group bulletin will be sent to the APRS-IS network. No data is returned to the pipeline.
If you do not specify APRS-IS server information, the message packet will be returned. You will have to send it via some other manner.

maml:alert.maml:para: General bulletins are generally transmitted a few times an hour for a few hours, and typically contain time-sensitive infrmation (such as weather status). For situations leading up an event, you should use an announcement.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Send-APRSBulletin -From GR8CLUB -BulletinID 2 -Message "Great Club's weekly check-in net will start at 7:00 PM on our repeater."

dev:remarks.maml:para: Send an APRS bulletin with ID number 2 and the provided message.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Send-APRSBulletin -From GR8CLUB -BulletinID 3 -Message "Great Club will be meeting at the community center tonight." -Latitude -12.345 -Longitude 67.890

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sends an APRS bulletin with ID number 3, the provided message, and a position report of 12.345°S, 67.890°E. Compatible APRS receivers may choose to plot this on a map.

maml:description.maml:para: Sends an APRS bulletin with a specified group name.
This cmdlet will generate and send an APRS bulletin with a given identifying number, to a named group.
Specify an APRS-IS server and/or port in order to send it via APRS-IS; otherwise, it will be printed to the screen.
The sender's callsign, with or without an SSID. This will almost always be yours or your club's callsign.
Provide a bulletin identifier between zero and nine (inclusive). The identifier is not defined in the APRS specification, and should be interpreted by the receiver.
Provide a group name. Group names can be up to five alphanumeric characters.

From the APRS specification: "A receiving station can specify a list of bulletin groups of interest. The list is defined internally by the user at the receiving station. If a group is selected from the list, the station will only copy bulletins for that group, plus any general bulletins. If the list is empty, all bulletins are received and generate alerts."
The bulletin text. Bulletin text may be up to 67 characters in length, and can contain any ASCII characters except for pipe ('|') and tilde ('~').
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Send this bulletin via APRS-IS without confirming. This will only happen if your $ConfirmPreference is set to "Low".
The TCP port used to connect to the APRS-IS server. By default, this is port 14580.
The fully-qualified domain name of the APRS-IS server. By default, rotate.aprs2.net is used, but it is best practice to provide your regional server's name.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run, and no data is sent to APRS-IS.
To include a position report, specify the -Latitude and -Longitude parameters, with your location in decimal degrees north. To specify a location in the Southern Hemisphere, use a negative number.
To include a position report, specify the -Latitude and -Longitude parameters, with your location in decimal degrees east. To specify a location in the Western Hemisphere, use a negative number.
Provide a bulletin identifier between zero and nine (inclusive). The identifier is not defined in the APRS specification, and should be interpreted by the receiver.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Send this bulletin via APRS-IS without confirming. This will only happen if your $ConfirmPreference is set to "Low".
The sender's callsign, with or without an SSID. This will almost always be yours or your club's callsign.
Provide a group name. Group names can be up to five alphanumeric characters.

From the APRS specification: "A receiving station can specify a list of bulletin groups of interest. The list is defined internally by the user at the receiving station. If a group is selected from the list, the station will only copy bulletins for that group, plus any general bulletins. If the list is empty, all bulletins are received and generate alerts."
The bulletin text. Bulletin text may be up to 67 characters in length, and can contain any ASCII characters except for pipe ('|') and tilde ('~').
The TCP port used to connect to the APRS-IS server. By default, this is port 14580.
The fully-qualified domain name of the APRS-IS server. By default, rotate.aprs2.net is used, but it is best practice to provide your regional server's name.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run, and no data is sent to APRS-IS.
To include a position report, specify the -Latitude and -Longitude parameters, with your location in decimal degrees north. To specify a location in the Southern Hemisphere, use a negative number.
To include a position report, specify the -Latitude and -Longitude parameters, with your location in decimal degrees east. To specify a location in the Western Hemisphere, use a negative number.
This cmdlet can accept message data through the pipeline.
If you specify APRS-IS server information, the group bulletin will be sent to the APRS-IS network. No data is returned to the pipeline.
If you do not specify APRS-IS server information, the message packet will be returned. You will have to send it via some other manner.

maml:alert.maml:para: General and group bulletins are generally transmitted a few times an hour for a few hours, and typically contain time-sensitive infrmation (such as weather status). For situations leading up an event, you should use an announcement.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Send-APRSGroupBulletin -From GR8CLUB -BulletinID 0 -GroupName "NET" -Message "Send CQ [space] msg to GR8CLUB to check into GreatClub's APRS net." -Force

dev:remarks.maml:para: Send an APRS bulletin with ID number 0 to group NET and the provided message.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Send-APRSGroupBulletin -From GR8CLUB -BulletinID 1 -GroupName "REPEATER" -Latitude 12.345 -Longitude -67.890 -Message "The repeater at 12.345°N, 67.890°E is down."

dev:remarks.maml:para: Send an APRS bulletin with ID number 1 to group REPEATER, and include a position report.

maml:description.maml:para: Sends a message to another user on the APRS network.
This cmdlet will send a message to another APRS user. Optionally, when sending via APRS-IS, an acknowledgement can be requested from the recipient.
The sender's callsign, with or without an SSID. This will almost always be yours or your club's callsign.
The recipient's callsign, or any other recipient name recognized by APRS.
The message text. It may be up to 67 characters in length, and can contain any ASCII characters except for pipe ('|'), tilde ('~'), and the opening curly brace ('{').

If this parameter is specified, the recipient's radio will be asked to confirm or reject the incoming message. Specify a five-character message identifier. Your radio should receive a message with the same identifier: for message E420, you will receive "ackE420" if they received it or "rejE420" if they did not.
While you can request acknowledgements with this cmdlet, you will need additional hardware to receive these responses. Additionally, the recipient's radio must support acknowledgements.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Send this message via APRS-IS without confirming. This will only happen if your $ConfirmPreference is set to "Low".
The TCP port used to connect to the APRS-IS server. By default, this is port 14580.
The fully-qualified domain name of the APRS-IS server. By default, rotate.aprs2.net is used, but it is best practice to provide your regional server's name.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run, and no data is sent to APRS-IS.
To include a position report, specify the -Latitude and -Longitude parameters, with your location in decimal degrees north. To specify a location in the Southern Hemisphere, use a negative number.
To include a position report, specify the -Latitude and -Longitude parameters, with your location in decimal degrees east. To specify a location in the Western Hemisphere, use a negative number.

If this parameter is specified, the recipient's radio will be asked to confirm or reject the incoming message. Specify a five-character message identifier. Your radio should receive a message with the same identifier: for message E420, you will receive "ackE420" if they received it or "rejE420" if they did not.
While you can request acknowledgements with this cmdlet, you will need additional hardware to receive these responses. Additionally, the recipient's radio must support acknowledgements.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Send this message via APRS-IS without confirming. This will only happen if your $ConfirmPreference is set to "Low".
The sender's callsign, with or without an SSID. This will almost always be yours or your club's callsign.
The message text. It may be up to 67 characters in length, and can contain any ASCII characters except for pipe ('|'), tilde ('~'), and the opening curly brace ('{').
The TCP port used to connect to the APRS-IS server. By default, this is port 14580.
The fully-qualified domain name of the APRS-IS server. By default, rotate.aprs2.net is used, but it is best practice to provide your regional server's name.
The recipient's callsign, or any other recipient name recognized by APRS.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run, and no data is sent to APRS-IS.
To include a position report, specify the -Latitude and -Longitude parameters, with your location in decimal degrees north. To specify a location in the Southern Hemisphere, use a negative number.
To include a position report, specify the -Latitude and -Longitude parameters, with your location in decimal degrees east. To specify a location in the Western Hemisphere, use a negative number.
This cmdlet can accept message data through the pipeline.
If you specify APRS-IS server information, the group bulletin will be sent to the APRS-IS network. No data is returned to the pipeline.
If you do not specify APRS-IS server information, the message packet will be returned. You will have to send it via some other manner.

maml:alert.maml:para: Messages are sent to one recipient. For contacting multiple people at once, consider using a bulletin, group bulletin, or announcement instead.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Send-APRSMessage -From Y0URCALL -To FR1END -Message "Hey, how's it going?" -Server noam.aprs2.net

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sends an APRS message with the specified text to the holder of the (fictitious) call sign FR1END.

command:example.maml:title: ----------------- Example 2: Via the Pipeline -----------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $jokes | Get-Random | Send-APRSMessage -From Y0URCALL -To FR1END -Server noam.aprs2.net

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sends a random joke from a specified list of jokes to the holder of the (fictitious) call sign FR1END.

command:example.maml:title: ----------------- Example 3: Acknowledgements -----------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Send-APRSMessage -From Y0URCALL -To FR1END -Message "This is important!" -Acknowledgement 69 -Server noam.aprs2.net

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sends a message to the holder of the (fictitious) call sign FR1END, tagging this as message #69. If the recipient's radio supports this feature, you will receive a reply stating if they acknowledged or rejected it. Note that this PowerShell module does not listen for replies, so you will need another APRS device (such as a radio) to listen for a response.

command:example.maml:title: --------------------- Example 4: Positions ---------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Send-APRSMessage -From 'Y0URCALL' -To 'FR1END' -Latitude 41.71479 -Longitude -72.72721 -Message "Arrived safely at ARRL headquarters!"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sends a message to FR1END which includes a position report.
